thread.title: NBN trying to cut cost of internet services to rural, regional Australia | The
thread.title_full: NBN trying to cut cost of internet services to rural, regional Australia | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: NBN trying to cut cost of internet services to rural, regional Australia | The
text:
Speaking at the National Press Club in Canberra today NBN boss Bill Morrow said the company was exploring ways to help smaller internet service providers to better compete with the nation’s largest telcos, including Telstra Optus and TPG Telecom.
Almost 30 per cent of the NBN is currently too expensive for very small internet providers to pay the backhaul costs needed to connect customers to the network and compete with the likes of Telstra.
The costly issue of paying for backhaul from regional areas goes back to the original architecture of NBN which is made up of 121 hubs across the country that connect to homes and businesses.
Phone and internet companies that sell NBN services across the country must build or rent cables to connect to all of these hubs. But because the cost to do so can run into the millions of dollars, it prices out many potential competitors from using the NBN.
Mr Morrow admitted today that because of Australia’s size, about 40 of these hubs were more expensive for many retailers to connect to but that the NBN was looking into ways to reduce the costs.
“What’s on our minds is whether this will present a barrier to entry that might limit retail offers, and in turn limit choice,” Mr Morrow said.
“If this turns out to be the case, there are a number of options we could explore to boost competition. However before we do anything, our preference would be to see the market respond.
“We are working with others who see a market opportunity by solving this remote regional point of entry (issue). At the end of the day, it’s about levelling the playing field and ensuring there is a low barrier to entry and we would hope the markets will do just this.”
Whether or not the nation’s larger internet providers come to the table and work with NBN to help smaller retailers connect to the network remains to be seen. Telcos like Telstra, Optus, TPG Telecom and M2 Group have made substantial investments to connect to these hubs and are understood to strongly oppose any changes.
Mr Morrow also used his speech to talk about how the NBN would create a “seismic digital eruption” by providing a platform to inject innovation as a real economic contributor.
“No-one knows this better than our new prime minister. He’s spoken many times of the fact that convergence and globalisation offer much more competition, but they also offer us much more opportunity,” Mr Morrow said.
“At the end of the day, the NBN will be the backbone of the digital economy.”
